Probably Curtius, whether drawing direct from Klitarchus or not, dressed up or recast many of his exaggerations as he saw fit at the time, but was too sober to load his book with recounting other marvels which were most likely at once dreary and incredible. There is also reason to think that Curtius, though in the main a reporter rather than a historian‚ did sometimes3 check the statements of his guide by those of more trustworthy authors such as Ptolemy‚ who with Aristobulus is the writer most relied upon by the judicious A1·rian‘². While therefore we must conclude that much in the work before us is overdrawn‚ the singular accuracy observable in many small points⁵ and in some descriptions of places6 sorbids us to regard it as a mere romance to be ranked with Xenophon’s Cyrepaedia or Johnson's Rassclas.
